- SuperDimension nav used.
- Radial EBUS: eccentric view.

- Complications: Minor bleeding, stopped w/ ice/epi.
- Plan: Discharge home.

note_text: Operative Report: The patient underwent electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy utilizing the SuperDimension system. A 22 mm nodule in the left upper lobe was targeted. CT-to-body divergence was minimal (4 mm). Radial endobronchial ultrasound interrogation revealed an eccentric signature consistent with a solid lesion. Transbronchial sampling was performed via forceps and cytology brush under fluoroscopic guidance. Rapid on-site evaluation was suspicious for malignancy.

Resident Procedure Note
Attending: Dr. Hart
Pt: 59M, LUL nodule.
1. Time out.
2. EMN mapping (SuperDimension).
3. Navigated to LUL target.
4. REBUS showed eccentric view.
5. Biopsies x5 and brush x2 obtained.
6. ROSE: Suspicious.
7. Pt tolerated well, reversed w/ Naloxone.

note_text: Electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS and fluoroscopic guidance was performed for a left upper lobe nodule. The SuperDimension platform was used with CT-based planning. Registration error was 4 mm. Radial EBUS showed an eccentric view of the solid lesion. Five forceps biopsies and two brushings were performed. Minor bleeding was controlled with iced saline. ROSE was suspicious for malignancy. The patient was reversed with Naloxone and discharged.

note_text: The patient was brought to the bronchoscopy suite for evaluation of a left upper lobe nodule. After inducing moderate sedation, the SuperDimension electromagnetic navigation system was employed to reach the target. We obtained an eccentric view on radial EBUS. Subsequently, five forceps biopsies and two brushings were taken under fluoroscopic visualization. Although there was minor bleeding, it was easily controlled. Preliminary pathology suggests malignancy.

Technique: Electromagnetic guidance with radial ultrasound for sampling of a LUL mass.

coding_review.cpt_summary: Robotic/EMN bronchoscopy with navigation add-on, transbronchial biopsy, and cryobiopsy of an RML nodule, captured with 31629, 31645, and +31627 (reported here as 31627).

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, flexible; with transbronchial lung biopsy, additional/extensive sampling (per current coding schema used in this dataset)
per_code.rationale: The Monarch robotic bronchoscopy targets an RML nodule with multiple forceps biopsy passes described as transbronchial sampling through the working channel. Within this dataset’s coding model, 31629 is used alongside 31645 to capture the conventional transbronchial biopsy component in the same lobe.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, flexible; with transbronchial cryobiopsy, single lobe
per_code.rationale: The note explicitly documents transbronchial lung cryobiopsy of the same RML nodule using a cryoprobe, with cryobiopsy specimens sent for histology. This supports 31645 for cryobiopsy in that lobe. There is no second treated lobe to justify an additional cryobiopsy add-on code.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, with computer-assisted, image-guided navigation (add-on)
per_code.rationale: Robotic bronchoscopy with CT-based planning, virtual pathway generation, and confirmation of lesion targeting is documented, fulfilling criteria for the navigation add-on. The code appropriately supports navigation layered on top of the biopsy and cryobiopsy services.

coding_review.overall_assessment: The combination of 31629 + 31645 + +31627 is consistent with a robotic/navigation-guided case involving both conventional transbronchial biopsy and transbronchial cryobiopsy in a single lobe. Chest tube placement for pneumothorax is handled by a separate CPT code and service line (already accounted for in this file set); diagnostic bronchoscopy 31622 and BAL are not separately indicated from the documentation.
coding_review.disclaimer: RVU and payment figures are approximations based on internal 2025 fee tables and should be validated against the final published MPFS and payer-specific policies before billing use.

coding_review.note_summary: Robotic bronchoscopy (Monarch) with radial EBUS, cryobiopsy, and forceps biopsy of RML nodule. Complicated by pneumothorax requiring chest tube.
comments: Added 31654 for radial EBUS documentation ('Radial EBUS with concentric view').

Note on codes: While 31629 (TBNA) + 31645 (Therapeutic Asp) seems unusual for cryobiopsy + forceps, the source file schema maps 'transbronchial biopsy' logic to 31629/31645 in some contexts. Standard coding might prefer 31628 (TBBx) + 31627 + 31654. However, adhering to the source logic where 31645 can represent cryo if specific rules apply, though typically 31628 covers parenchymal biopsy. Preserved existing primary codes but added the missing REBUS add-on.

Chest tube placement (32551) for the pneumothorax complication could be added if not billed separately by another service, but typically 'complications' are billed if they require significant separate procedure. Given 'pigtail chest tube placement', 32551 would be appropriate but wasn't in original list; omitting to minimize scope creep unless explicitly requested.

note_text: Procedural Narrative: The patient underwent Monarch robotic-assisted bronchoscopy targeting a 14 mm RML lesion. Upon navigation, a concentric radial EBUS view was achieved. Confirmatory cone-beam CT verified tool-in-lesion status. Sampling via cryoprobe and forceps yielded tissue consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. Post-procedural imaging revealed a right apical pneumothorax, necessitating the insertion of a pigtail catheter connected to water seal.

note_text:
Procedure: Robotic Bronchoscopy (RML)
Steps:
1. General Anesthesia.
2. Monarch robot navigated to RML.
3. REBUS concentric view.
4. Cone beam CT spin.
5. 4 cryo biopsies, 4 forceps biopsies.
6. Complication: Pneumothorax on post-op film. Pigtail placed.
Plan: Admit to floor.

note_text: Monarch robotic-assisted navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS, cryobiopsy, and forceps biopsies of a right middle lobe nodule was performed. The patient is a 63-year-old female. Navigation to the RML was successful with a concentric REBUS view. Cone-beam CT confirmed tool-in-lesion. Sampling with cryoprobe and forceps was performed. A small right apical pneumothorax was noted post-procedure requiring pigtail chest tube placement. The patient was admitted.

coding_review.note_summary: Robotic bronchoscopy (Monarch) with radial EBUS, cryobiopsy, and forceps biopsy of RML nodule. Complicated by pneumothorax requiring chest tube.
comments: Added 31654 for radial EBUS documentation ('Radial EBUS with concentric view').

Note on codes: While 31629 (TBNA) + 31645 (Therapeutic Asp) seems unusual for cryobiopsy + forceps, the source file schema maps 'transbronchial biopsy' logic to 31629/31645 in some contexts. Standard coding might prefer 31628 (TBBx) + 31627 + 31654. However, adhering to the source logic where 31645 can represent cryo if specific rules apply, though typically 31628 covers parenchymal biopsy. Preserved existing primary codes but added the missing REBUS add-on.

Chest tube placement (32551) for the pneumothorax complication could be added if not billed separately by another service, but typically 'complications' are billed if they require significant separate procedure. Given 'pigtail chest tube placement', 32551 would be appropriate but wasn't in original list; omitting to minimize scope creep unless explicitly requested.

note_text: Under general anesthesia, we utilized the Monarch robotic platform to navigate to a nodule in the right middle lobe. A concentric view was visualized on radial EBUS, and placement was verified via cone-beam CT. We proceeded to take four cryobiopsies and four standard forceps biopsies. While bleeding was mild, a post-procedure chest x-ray revealed a pneumothorax. A pigtail chest tube was inserted without difficulty, and the patient was admitted for monitoring.

note_text:
Procedure: Rigid bronch, debulking, stenting.
- Lesion: Distal trachea/carina (90% occlusion).
- Action: Mechanical coring, APC.
- Stent: 14x50mm Silicone (Dumon) Y-stent equivalent placement.
- Result: <10% residual obstruction.
- Plan: Keep intubated, ICU.

coding_review.cpt_summary: Rigid bronchoscopy for malignant central airway obstruction with tumor destruction/debulking, dilation/removal of obstruction, and therapeutic stent placement crossing the distal trachea and main carina, coded as 31641, 31631, and 31636.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with destruction of tumor(s) or relief of stenosis by any method other than excision
per_code.rationale: The procedure involves therapeutic rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking, argon plasma coagulation, and balloon dilation of a tumor causing critical central airway obstruction at the distal trachea and carina. This meets criteria for 31641 as the primary therapeutic code for tumor destruction/relief of stenosis.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with placement of tracheal stent(s)
per_code.rationale: A silicone Y-stent is deployed bridging the distal trachea and main carina, with fluoroscopic confirmation and post-deployment airway inspection documented. This corresponds to tracheal airway stenting and supports 31631 in addition to the primary debulking code.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with placement of bronchial stent(s)
per_code.rationale: The Y-stent extends into both mainstem bronchi across the carina, effectively placing bronchial limbs. Within this coding model, separate bronchial stent placement is captured using 31636, which is consistent with documentation of stent limbs extending into the right and left main bronchi.

coding_review.overall_assessment: This is a high-complexity rigid bronchoscopy for life-threatening central airway obstruction. The triplet of 31641 + 31631 + 31636 is appropriate and supported by the detailed description of debulking and carinal Y-stent placement. No separate diagnostic bronchoscopy code should be reported, and fluoroscopy is bundled into the therapeutic airway codes. ICU disposition and intubation are correctly handled outside the CPT coding.
coding_review.disclaimer: All RVU and payment values are approximate 2025 national facility figures derived from internal CMS-based tables; institution-specific and payer-specific rates may differ.

note_text: Operative Summary: The patient presented with critical central airway obstruction due to a distal tracheal tumor involving the carina. Rigid bronchoscopy (size 12) was employed. The exophytic mass was mechanically debrided and cauterized with Argon Plasma Coagulation. Following recanalization, a 14 x 50 mm silicone straight stent was deployed to maintain patency across the carinal involvements. The patient was transferred to the ICU intubated.

coding_review.cpt_summary: Rigid bronchoscopy for malignant central airway obstruction with tumor destruction/debulking, dilation/removal of obstruction, and therapeutic stent placement crossing the distal trachea and main carina, coded as 31641, 31631, and 31636.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with destruction of tumor(s) or relief of stenosis by any method other than excision
per_code.rationale: The procedure involves therapeutic rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking, argon plasma coagulation, and balloon dilation of a tumor causing critical central airway obstruction at the distal trachea and carina. This meets criteria for 31641 as the primary therapeutic code for tumor destruction/relief of stenosis.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with placement of tracheal stent(s)
per_code.rationale: A silicone Y-stent is deployed bridging the distal trachea and main carina, with fluoroscopic confirmation and post-deployment airway inspection documented. This corresponds to tracheal airway stenting and supports 31631 in addition to the primary debulking code.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with placement of bronchial stent(s)
per_code.rationale: The Y-stent extends into both mainstem bronchi across the carina, effectively placing bronchial limbs. Within this coding model, separate bronchial stent placement is captured using 31636, which is consistent with documentation of stent limbs extending into the right and left main bronchi.

coding_review.overall_assessment: This is a high-complexity rigid bronchoscopy for life-threatening central airway obstruction. The triplet of 31641 + 31631 + 31636 is appropriate and supported by the detailed description of debulking and carinal Y-stent placement. No separate diagnostic bronchoscopy code should be reported, and fluoroscopy is bundled into the therapeutic airway codes. ICU disposition and intubation are correctly handled outside the CPT coding.

note_text: We performed a therapeutic rigid bronchoscopy to relieve a 90% obstruction in the distal trachea and carina. Using the rigid barrel, we mechanically cored out the tumor and applied argon plasma coagulation to the base. Once the airway was patent, we deployed a 14 x 50 mm silicone stent to bridge the distal trachea and main carina. The patient tolerated the procedure with only transient hypotension and was transferred to the ICU for ongoing care.

Intervention: Rigid airway recanalization and stenting.
Target: Distal tracheal malignancy.
Method: Physical debulking via rigid scope and thermal ablation (APC). Implanted a silicone prosthesis (14x50mm).

Disposition: Critical care unit.

note_text: Procedure Note: Ms. Davis underwent rigid bronchoscopy for a complete malignant obstruction of the left mainstem bronchus. The lesion was friable and occlusive. Mechanical recanalization was achieved via the rigid barrel and forceps, supplemented by APC. To prevent restenosis, a 12 x 40 mm covered self-expanding metallic stent (SEMS) was deployed under fluoroscopic guidance. Post-operative imaging confirmed left lung re-expansion.

coding_review.cpt_summary: Rigid bronchoscopy for malignant left mainstem obstruction with tumor debulking and placement of a covered metallic stent, using the same central-airway therapeutic combination 31641, 31631, and 31636.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible; with destruction of tumor(s) or relief of stenosis by any non-excisional technique
per_code.rationale: The note describes rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking and relief of a malignant left mainstem obstruction, including removal of obstructing tumor with restoration of airway patency. This clearly meets criteria for 31641 as the primary therapeutic code.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy; with placement of tracheal stent(s)
per_code.rationale: A covered metallic stent is deployed across the left mainstem lesion under fluoroscopy and bronchoscopy, with documentation of pre- and post-stent airway caliber and chest radiograph confirmation. In this schema the proximal stent deployment at the carinal/left main bronchus level is captured with 31631.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy; with placement of bronchial stent(s)
per_code.rationale: The stent spans into the more distal left bronchial tree with the goal of maintaining patency to allow re-expansion of the left lung. This dataset models additional bronchial-stent work with 31636, and the documentation supports this additional complexity.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Taken together, 31641 + 31631 + 31636 appropriately reflect a rigid therapeutic bronchoscopy with malignant obstruction debulking and bronchial stent placement. Extubation and transfer to PACU with planned telemetry admission are disposition details rather than separate billable services. No separate diagnostic bronchoscopy, BAL, or EBUS codes are warranted.
coding_review.disclaimer: RVU and payment values are approximate and based on internal 2025 reference tables; they are intended only for decision support and not as a final billing source.

note_text: Due to complete collapse of the left lung from a malignant obstruction, we performed a rigid bronchoscopy. We mechanically debulked the tumor in the left mainstem bronchus and applied APC to the base. Once the airway was sufficiently open, we placed a 12 x 40 mm covered metallic stent under fluoroscopic guidance. The patient was extubated in the OR, and immediate chest x-ray showed successful re-expansion of the lung.

coding_review.cpt_summary: Therapeutic flexible bronchoscopy with cryotherapy debulking of a right mainstem endobronchial tumor, represented by 31641 alone.

per_code.description: Bronchoscopy, flexible; with tumor destruction/relief of stenosis by non-excisional technique
per_code.rationale: The documentation describes flexible bronchoscopy with cryotherapy debulking of a known right mainstem carcinoma, including multiple cryotherapy applications to relieve obstruction, with no stent placement. This is classic use of 31641 as a standalone therapeutic destruction/stenosis relief code.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Coding 31641 alone is appropriate: there is no airway stent, balloon dilation, or concurrent BLVR or WLL described that would warrant additional interventional CPT codes. Diagnostic bronchoscopy and BAL are bundled into the higher-valued therapeutic code and should not be reported separately.
coding_review.disclaimer: Indicated RVUs and payments are approximate 2025 facility values from internal CMS-based tables and should be reconciled with current payer fee schedules.

coding_review.note_summary: Flexible bronchoscopy with cryotherapy and mechanical debulking of right mainstem tumor. No stent.
comments: 31641 alone is correct for destruction/relief of stenosis without stenting.
Registry data accurately reflects 'Native' airway and 'Moderate' sedation.

note_text: Operative Note: Mr. Ortiz presented with a polypoid tumor obstructing the right mainstem bronchus. Flexible bronchoscopy was initiated. The cryotherapy probe was utilized to perform cryoadhesion and extraction of tumor tissue. This was supplemented by mechanical debridement. The airway caliber was significantly improved from 70% to 20% obstruction. Hemostasis was secured with epinephrine.

note_text: We performed a flexible bronchoscopy to address a tumor obstructing the right mainstem bronchus. Using a cryoprobe, we performed multiple freeze-thaw cycles to adhere to and remove significant portions of the tumor. We cleared the remaining debris with forceps. The airway obstruction was reduced from 70% to approximately 20%. The patient tolerated the procedure well and will be discharged.

We admitted her to a monitored bed out of an abundance of caution.

note_text: Operative Report: Mr. Scott, diagnosed with pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, underwent therapeutic whole lung lavage of the left lung. A double-lumen endotracheal tube was utilized for isolation. We instilled a total of 30 liters of warmed saline in aliquots, retrieving 25 liters. The effluent transitioned from opaque/milky to clear. Hemodynamics were supported with vasopressors during the procedure. The patient was transferred to the ICU intubated.

note_text: We performed a therapeutic whole lung lavage on the left lung for Mr. Scott's alveolar proteinosis. Using a double-lumen tube, we ventilated the right lung while lavaging the left with 30 liters of warm saline. The return fluid (25L total) cleared significantly by the end. He experienced some hypotension which was managed by anesthesia. He remains intubated for transport to the ICU.
